channel.title: math.LO updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.LO updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: Truth and meaningfulness
item.description: arXiv:2507.08289v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: I outline a new theory of truth that resolves the classical and constructive versions of the liar paradox. The theory features a provably consistent axiomatization of a global self-applicative truth predicate. Truth is defined using Tarski's "convention T", but compositionality is automatic. The correct, non-paradoxical form of Frege's Basic Law V is given. This paper is a (very) condensed version of the account of truth advanced in my recent book *Constructive Countablism*.
item.dc:creator: Nik Weaver

item.title: Ultrafilters in the random real model
item.description: arXiv:2507.08346v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We prove that \textsf{P}-points (even strong P-points) and Gruff ultrafilters exist in any forcing extension obtained by adding fewer than $\aleph_{\omega}% $-many random reals to a model of \textsf{CH. }These results improve and correct previous theorems that can be found in the literature.
item.dc:creator: Alan Dow, Osvaldo Guzm\'an

item.title: A model-thoeretic version of Tarski's theorem
item.description: arXiv:2507.08463v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Working in any model theoretic structure, we single out a class of definable bipartite graphs that admit definable, close to perfect matchings. We use this result to prove a strengthening of Tarski's theorem for the definable setting.
item.dc:creator: Jana Ma\v{r}\'ikov\'a

item.title: The complexity of classifying continuous t-norms up to isomorphism
item.description: arXiv:2408.16456v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: It is shown that the isomorphism relation between continuous t-norms is Borel bireducible with the relation of order isomorphism between linear orders on the set of natural numbers, and therefore, it is a Borel complete equivalence relation.
item.dc:creator: Jialiang He, Lili Shen, Yi Zhou

item.title: Iterated jump noncomputability and compactness
item.description: arXiv:2506.20620v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: We use reverse mathematics to analyze "iterated jump" versions of the following four principles: the atomic model theorem with subenumerable types (AST), the diagonally noncomputable principle (DNR), weak weak K\H{o}nig's lemma (WWKL), and weak K\H{o}nig's lemma (WKL). The logical relationships between these principles are summarized in Figure 1 and include, among other things, an infinite chain and an infinite antichain, the latter of which represents a strong form of non-linearity in terms of provability strength among "natural" combinatorial principles.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Dooley
